The 'Hellenic Navy' ('HN') (, PolemikÃ³ NaftikÃ³, abbreviated 'Î Î') is the naval
force of Greece, part of the Greek Armed Forces. The modern Greek navy has its
roots in the naval forces of various Aegean Islands, which fought in the Greek
War of Independence. During the periods of monarchy (1833â1924 and 1936â1973) it
was known as the 'Royal Navy' ('ÎÎ±ÏÎ¹Î»Î¹ÎºÏÎ½ ÎÎ±ÏÏÎ¹ÎºÏÎ½', VasilikÃ³n NaftikÃ³n,
abbreviated 'ÎÎ').

The total displacement of all the navy's vessels is approximately 150,000 tons.

The motto of the Hellenic Navy is "ÎÎ­Î³Î± ÏÎ¿ ÏÎ·Ï ÎÎ±Î»Î¬ÏÏÎ·Ï ÎÏÎ¬ÏÎ¿Ï" from
Thucydides' account of Pericles' oration on the eve of the Peloponnesian
War. Thucydides,  This has been roughly translated as "Great is the
country that controls the sea". The Hellenic Navy's emblem
consists of an anchor in front of a crossed Christian cross and trident, with
the cross symbolizing Greek Orthodoxy, and the trident symbolizing Poseidon,
the god of the sea in Greek mythology. Pericles' words are written across the
top of the emblem.
